repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - National Environmental
            Policy Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory,
            with project sustainability highly likely. The overall
            performances of both the World Bank and the borrower are
            rated satisfactory. These were the lessons learned from the
            project: Project design and implementation, Simplicity and
            flexibility in project design are two essential
            characteristics for loans with short implementation periods.
            Avoiding complexity in project design (e.g. clear and
            concise components, concrete objectives in line with
            institutional capacity, realistic timing in output delivery,
            etc.), allows for smoother implementation. Similarly,
            projects that build in a flexible approach (e.g. confined,
            demand-driven capacity building activities) are better
            equipped to adapt to unforeseen shocks encountered during
            implementation, ensuring their completion. Regarding
            implementation, adopting a participatory consultative
            process to develop project outputs and implement project
            activities enhances continuity and sustainability in project
            execution. While the degree of success and sustainability
            varied among the 8 pilots, the most successful pilot
            implementation teams were those that fully involved the
            local communities in all decision-making, building ownership
            and trust from the proposal stage until the closure of the project.

5083282.majtheme: Public sector governance,Environment and natural resource management,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Rule of law

repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - National Environmental
            Policy Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The National Environmental Policy Reform
            Project's objective is to establish the basis for
            improved environmental management by defining environmental
            policy reforms and elaborating a National Environmental
            Management Program (NEMP) through a learning and
            participatory process. There are three components in this
            project. First, supporting policy and institutional reform
            will define priority legal, institutional, and fiscal
            reforms to improve environmental management, define sectoral
            action plans for environmental management reform, and
            develop a NEMP. Second, developing pilot activities will
            develop innovative models for natural resource management,
            and increase decentralization of environmental functions.
            The third component, aiming at building capacity for project
            management and providing technical training, will strengthen
            capacity for environmental planning and management in key
            environmental agencies; ensure efficient and effective
            project implementation; and develop the needed human
            resources for the new institutional arrangements resulting
            from the reforms.
